title: Algorithmic prompting
text:
Workshop link and Schedule
Algorithmic prompting means giving clear, step-by-step instructions that guide AI to do useful work. In this course, you’ll learn to turn plain-language questions into prompts that create tables, charts, and quick data checks. You won’t need deep coding skills—just a method for breaking problems into small, repeatable steps. By the end, you’ll use algorithmic prompts to automate routine tasks and explore data with confidence.
Coding for dummies workshop is for anyone with little or no programming experience who wants to use Generative AI for data analysis. In the first two sessions, you’ll get comfortable in Google Colab, learn the basics of AI-aided low-code programming, and see how a few lines of Python can automate routine tasks and streamline your workflow.
In the remaining sessions, we’ll dive into AI-assisted analysis with Python: “chatting with your data” in natural language to create and manipulate tables, clean and transform datasets, and build clear visualizations. By the end, you’ll know how to combine low-code Python tools with modern AI assistants to load, explore, and visualize data efficiently—producing reproducible notebooks you can adapt to your own research and reporting.

To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Product Requirements Document (PRD)
text:
Build a tiny, beginner-friendly Python function that tests whether a string is a palindrome. It will be used in a Day-1 workshop segment to teach variables, strings, conditionals, and printing in Google Colab (or any Python 3 environment).




Goals

Provide a clear function (is_palindrome(text) -> bool) with a few lines of code.
Demonstrate problem decomposition: normalize → compare → return.
Include a tiny CLI/print demo cell so learners see outputs.

Non-Goals

No GUI, web API, or file I/O.
No heavy NLP; keep logic readable and short.






As a learner, I can run is_palindrome("racecar") and see True.
As a learner, I can paste phrases like "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama!" and still get the right answer after normalization.
As an instructor, I can show how to add/remove normalization (punctuation, spacing, case) and see tests pass/fail predictably.





Function

Signature: def is_palindrome(text: str) -> bool:
Returns True if text reads identically forward and backward after normalization; else False.

Normalization (default behavior)

Lowercase via .casefold() (safer for Unicode).
Remove all non-alphanumeric characters.
Remove spaces.
(Optional, commented line) Unicode normalization to NFC for edge cases.

Demo/Printing

A short main/demo cell that:

Defines a small test list and prints input → result, e.g., print(f"{s!r}: {is_palindrome(s)}").


Structure

≤ 15 lines in the core function (readability first).
Inline comments that map back to “variables, strings, conditionals, printing”.






Clarity: Prefer readable Python over clever one-liners.
Portability: Works in Python 3.9+ (Colab default OK).
Teaching Value: Code is easy to modify (e.g., toggling normalization).





A .py snippet or Colab cell containing is_palindrome plus a demo cell.
Running the demo prints correct results for the acceptance tests below.
Learners can change normalization lines and observe expected changes.





is_palindrome("racecar") → True
is_palindrome("RaceCar") → True
is_palindrome("hello") → False
is_palindrome("A man, a plan, a canal: Panama!") → True
is_palindrome("") → True (empty string counts as palindrome)
is_palindrome("Åsa")

With casefold only: False
If normalized to alphanumerics only and reversed strictly: False
(Instructor note: use to discuss Unicode & normalization limits.)






Show the raw comparison (text == text[::-1]).
Add lowercasing; re-run tests.
Add removal of non-alphanumerics; re-run tests.
Print friendly messages to stdout; map to workshop topics (variables/conditionals/printing).




import unicodedata
import re

def is_palindrome(text: str) -> bool:
    # 1) normalize (toggle/comment lines to teach step-by-step)
    s = text.casefold()
    # s = unicodedata.normalize("NFC", s)  # optional unicode normalization
    s = re.sub(r"[^0-9a-zA-Z]+", "", s)    # keep only alphanumerics

    # 2) compare with reverse
    return s == s[::-1]

# Demo / printing (for Day 1)
samples = [
    "racecar",
    "RaceCar",
    "hello",
    "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama!",
    "",
    "Åsa",
]
for s in samples:
    print(f"{s!r} -> {is_palindrome(s)}")




Unicode edge cases: Explain that diacritics/ligatures can be tricky; show optional unicodedata.normalize.
Over-normalization: Removing all non-alphanumerics may change meaning; keep this as a teaching point.





Code cell (or palindrome.py) with the function and demo.
A short worksheet prompt: “Add an elif branch to print why a string failed (case vs punctuation).”





Learners can explain the three steps (normalize → compare → return).
≥80% of learners pass all acceptance tests within 10 minutes.
Learners can modify normalization and predict outcomes correctly.

title: Product Requirements Document (PRD)
text:
Build a tiny, beginner-friendly Python function that tests whether a string is a palindrome. It will be used in a Day-1 workshop segment to teach variables, strings, conditionals, and printing in Google Colab (or any Python 3 environment).




Goals

Provide a clear function (is_palindrome(text) -> bool) with a few lines of code.
Demonstrate problem decomposition: normalize → compare → return.
Include a tiny CLI/print demo cell so learners see outputs.

Non-Goals

No GUI, web API, or file I/O.
No heavy NLP; keep logic readable and short.






As a learner, I can run is_palindrome("racecar") and see True.
As a learner, I can paste phrases like "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama!" and still get the right answer after normalization.
As an instructor, I can show how to add/remove normalization (punctuation, spacing, case) and see tests pass/fail predictably.

Signature: def is_palindrome(text: str) -> bool:
Returns True if text reads identically forward and backward after normalization; else False.

Normalization (default behavior)

Lowercase via .casefold() (safer for Unicode).
Remove all non-alphanumeric characters.
Remove spaces.
(Optional, commented line) Unicode normalization to NFC for edge cases.

Demo/Printing

A short main/demo cell that:

Defines a small test list and prints input → result, e.g., print(f"{s!r}: {is_palindrome(s)}").


Structure

≤ 15 lines in the core function (readability first).
Inline comments that map back to “variables, strings, conditionals, printing”.






Clarity: Prefer readable Python over clever one-liners.
Portability: Works in Python 3.9+ (Colab default OK).

A .py snippet or Colab cell containing is_palindrome plus a demo cell.
Running the demo prints correct results for the acceptance tests below.
Learners can change normalization lines and observe expected changes.





is_palindrome("racecar") → True
is_palindrome("RaceCar") → True
is_palindrome("hello") → False
is_palindrome("A man, a plan, a canal: Panama!") → True
is_palindrome("") → True (empty string counts as palindrome)
is_palindrome("Åsa")

With casefold only: False
If normalized to alphanumerics only and reversed strictly: False
(Instructor note: use to discuss Unicode & normalization limits.)






Show the raw comparison (text == text[::-1]).
Add lowercasing; re-run tests.
Add removal of non-alphanumerics; re-run tests.
Print friendly messages to stdout; map to workshop topics (variables/conditionals/printing).




import unicodedata
import re

def is_palindrome(text: str) -> bool:
    # 1) normalize (toggle/comment lines to teach step-by-step)
    s = text.casefold()
    # s = unicodedata.normalize("NFC", s)  # optional unicode normalization
    s = re.sub(r"[^0-9a-zA-Z]+", "", s)    # keep only alphanumerics

    # 2) compare with reverse
    return s == s[::-1]

# Demo / printing (for Day 1)
samples = [
    "racecar",
    "RaceCar",
    "hello",
    "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama!",
    "",
    "Åsa",
]
for s in samples:
    print(f"{s!r} -> {is_palindrome(s)}")




Unicode edge cases: Explain that diacritics/ligatures can be tricky; show optional unicodedata.normalize.
Over-normalization: Removing all non-alphanumerics may change meaning; keep this as a teaching point.





Code cell (or palindrome.py) with the function and demo.
A short worksheet prompt: “Add an elif branch to print why a string failed (case vs punctuation).”





Learners can explain the three steps (normalize → compare → return).
≥80% of learners pass all acceptance tests within 10 minutes.
Learners can modify normalization and predict outcomes correctly.

title: Coding for Dummies — Workshop Program
text:
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

# Adjust path if your TSV has a different name/location
tsv_path = Path("schedule.tsv")

# Read TSV
df = pd.read_csv(tsv_path, sep="\t")

# Create sortable keys
day_order = {f"Day {i}": i for i in range(1, 6)}
hour_order = {"1": 1, "2": 2, "3": 3}

df["DaySort"] = df["Day"].map(day_order)
df["HourSort"] = df["Hour"].astype(str).map(hour_order)

df = df.sort_values(["DaySort", "HourSort", "Session Type"]).drop(columns=["DaySort","HourSort"])

# Render as HTML table (Quarto will display this nicely)
df

title: Coding for Dummies — Workshop Program
text:
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

# Adjust path if your TSV has a different name/location
tsv_path = Path("schedule.tsv")

# Read TSV
df = pd.read_csv(tsv_path, sep="\t")

# Create sortable keys
day_order = {f"Day {i}": i for i in range(1, 6)}
hour_order = {"1": 1, "2": 2, "3": 3}

df["DaySort"] = df["Day"].map(day_order)
df["HourSort"] = df["Hour"].astype(str).map(hour_order)

df = df.sort_values(["DaySort", "HourSort", "Session Type"]).drop(columns=["DaySort","HourSort"])

# Render as HTML table (Quarto will display this nicely)
df

title: Coding for Dummies — Workshop Program
text:
some info

from IPython.display import display, Markdown, HTML

# Use the already-sorted df from the previous cell
for day, g in df.groupby("Day", sort=False):
    display(Markdown(f"### {day}"))
    # Drop the repeated Day column and render a clean sub-table
    display(HTML(g.drop(columns=["Day"]).to_html(index=False)))
